{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3484906,"name":null,"username":"PanicLemming","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/paniclemming/{size}/234749_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-16T20:28:23.507Z","cooked":"

Can someone elaborate on this statment

By default, the project uses a duty cycle encoder connected to a turn Spark Max. When using another absolute encoder (such as a CANcoder or HELIUM Canandmag), we recommend resetting the relative encoder based on the absolute encoder; the relative encoder can then be used for PID control.

Source: Advantage Kit Docs

Why is it recommended to only use the Abs. Encoder to reset the motor relative Encoder? Wouldn’t using the relative encoder be subject to drift over a match?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":2,"updated_at":"2025-01-16T20:28:23.507Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":59,"readers_count":58,"score":86.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482126,"topic_slug":"advantage-kit-spark-template-w-abs-encoder","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.advantagekit.org/getting-started/template-projects/spark-swerve-template#customization","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Spark Swerve Template | AdvantageKit","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61162,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Can you hand me the funny thing (the ziptie gun)?"},"post_url":"/t/advantage-kit-spark-template-w-abs-encoder/482126/1","custom_user_title":"Can you hand me the funny thing (the ziptie gun)?","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3485285,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T02:18:20.091Z","cooked":"

When using an encoder not connected directly to the Spark, the only way to take advantage of on-controller PID loops is to use the internal encoder on the NEO/Vortex. It won’t drift over time since the two sensors are mechanically coupled, and swerve modules tend to have very minimal backlash.
